page.title: 02Outline history of our area
page.content: Early development was restricted by the marshes to the high ground of the hamlets of Hordley and Tetchill with Frankton's development largely to the north of our area. The drainage of the moors saw the growth of outlying farms but it is the coming of the canal that really shaped the landscape. The idea first proposed was to link Shrewsbury with the Mersey at Ellesmere Port.Work on the Shrewsbury line stopped at Weston in 1797, but Frankton grew as a canal centre with lines going to Mid Wales,Llangollen and to Whitchurch and beyond.The canal handled peat, bricks, coal, limestone and stone that would have been important inputs to the landscape. The canals were officially closed in 1944. Since the war,Tetchill has attracted new housing although the rest of the area shows signs of rural decline.
